message.content:
Hendiadys (also spelled hendiady or hendyads) are phrases that combine two verbs to form a single sentence. In other words, they are phrasal verbs where the verb and its object are combined into one word. They are common in Greek and Latin but not as frequently used in English. 

For example: "to run after" can be expressed as "chase", "to look for" can be expressed as "search", or "to become angry" can be expressed as "flare up".
